awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Ethical and Methodological Challenges in Social Media Research
awd_abstract_narration:
An estimated 90% of youth are engaged in social media daily, and most are using multiple platforms. By all accounts, this is a critical space for exploring psychological development, stigma, and sociality. Yet little is known about what their day-to-day engagement within social media actually looks like. As an Early-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER), this project explores the ethical and methodological challenges of conducting human subjects research when recruitment is solicited through social media accounts. The ethics and logistics of capturing data riddled with identifying information, such as photos, screen names, posts about locations, posts where identifiable information is tagged, etc. is a challenge in terms of storing the data, analyzing it, making it available in a publicly accessible repository, and sharing it in resulting publications and presentations. What challenges does this research platform present for the removal of identifying information? To what extent does cleaning the data to protect anonymity impact the researcher's ability to convey the multidimensionality and richness of what happens in these social media realms? Does the process of protecting anonymity impact the type and amount of digital data gathered/captured? A central goal of this project is to explore the ethical and logistical boundaries of conducing participant observation in these private social media realms. As a project aimed at understanding the dynamics of constantly evolving technologies and their impact on work, this project contributes to NSF's investment in Work at the Human-Technology Frontier. 

Dr. Nicole Taylor of Texas State University, San Marcos, will conduct research on a sample of 50 male and female undergraduate students aged 18-22. This population was chosen because little is known about how college students experience and negotiate stigma in online social media forums. Researchers have established that the college years represent a period of major transition in nearly all areas of life, which influence social, physical, and psychological development, as well as future productivity in the workforce. The research setting serves an ethnically diverse student population and therefore provides an opportunity to generate a more reliable, robust, and representative research sample. Methods will include (1) a brief participant survey to gather demographic and social media use information; (2) participant observation within the 2-3 social media platforms most commonly used by the study population; (3) semi-structured interviews with participants; (4) focus group interviews with participants and their friends. A central goal of this exploratory research is to develop and pilot a method for conducting participant observation within the most commonly used social media platforms among college students. Dr. Taylor will explore the ethical and logistical boundaries of conducting participant observation in these more private social media realms where network invitations must be invited and accepted. For example, how can social media data be captured in a way that maintains participant anonymity and follows ethical guidelines, while also maintaining the fluid nature of youth engagements with social media? Findings will be disseminated in such a way as to impact public health efforts, which are typically based on large scale quantitative surveys, by offering in-depth accounts of how a diverse group of youth negotiate the intersection of their online and real world communities.

por.por_cntn:
This project primarily aimed to develop and pilot an ethically sound method for gathering, anonymizing, and publishing image data from individuals' social media accounts, including Instagram, Snapchat, Twitter, and Facebook. A secondary objective was to explore how college students are connecting with each other and constructing their identities online as well as the effects of social media on their body image and sense of self. We interviewed sixty-two college students, captured posts and comment threads from their social media accounts, and facilitated focus group discussions.

Today, through digital technology, users constantly create and share information about themselves. For researchers bound by Institutional Review Board (IRB) expectations that they make “reasonable efforts to maintain confidentiality,” such technology represents an ethical challenge. We found that it is not possible for researchers to guarantee confidentiality in social media studies that capture images due to the existence of highly sophisticated and widely available facial recognition technology that anyone with internet access can use to identify a participant. Specifically, we tested photos captured from our participants' social media sites by uploading them to Google Images, a free online search service. Google Images compares an uploaded image to billions of images in Google’s databases, comparing pixels for similar patterns.

If a research participant has a large social media following, appears in a popular publication, or simply posts photos of themselves across multiple social media platforms, the chances increase for their data to be collected and for them to be identifiable despite attempts to anonymize that data. To attempt to maintain confidentiality, a researcher might believe that blurring facial features or covering a participant’s eyes with black bars, using programs such as Photoshop, can be effective. Edits such as these essentially make a person unidentifiable to most human eyes, but a computer has the ability to compare other pixels left intact in the image, such as the leaf pattern in a tree in the background or the color and pattern of a person’s shirt. These pixel patterns functionally work as digital fingerprints.

Our findings have implications for protecting participant confidentiality, digital publishing, legality, and participant safety. In the U.S. it is possible to subpoena research data as evidence against an individual, which means that gathering identifiable images from participants' social media accounts could put them at risk. Additionally, the dynamic and global nature of connectivity in social media means that if a research participant is identifiable, people in their social network could be identified as well. For example, posts or comment threads that include friends from countries with strict social media policies, such as China and Iran, could put them at risk legally and socially. Moreover, most academic journals publish digitally. If journals publish digital images of subjects, those images could all potentially be used for identification purposes.

In terms of our secondary research aim to understand how youth construct identities in social media and the effects of social media on their sense of self and body image, we found that online identities are highly constructed, much more so than in face-to-face contexts. In anthropology, we understand identity as socially constructed through everyday practices and social interaction. This is true for social media as well, but the constructed nature of self is much more intensive and premeditated online. Youth felt pressure to maintain multiple selves—their "in real life" self as well as their highly constructed selves across social media platforms. Social norms differed significantly enough in different platforms that participants had to be vigilant about maintaining appropriate identities across their sites.

Another theme that emerged as particularly strong is that particpants felt pressure to live up to an expectation of college life as fun, adventurous, carefree, and highly social. This pressure invited social comparison, leading many to feel inadequate in terms of both their lives and their physical appearance. Additionally, having a constant presence on social media was very important to students’ sense of self—it helped them feel like others know they exist and are alive. As such, they felt pressure to post on multiple forums regularly to avoid losing followers or friends. Additionally, one of the strongest social norms that emerged across social media platforms was an imperative to be happy and positive all of the time. This resulted in many feeling internally conflicted, as they highly valued authenticity and expression of a full range of emotions; yet, they were bound by social media norms to hide sad or negative emotions.

Our findings underscore the rapidly changing nature of internet technology as well as the need for interdisciplinary collaboration. Researchers across disciplines are increasingly studying social media, and our work highlights and troubleshoots ethical issues that can inform social media research in the future. Additionally, our work makes visible these routinized practices in social media that have social and emotional impacts on young people today.
